lines.content: Naruto is a **desktop app for managing todos, events, and deadlines, optimized for use via a Command Line Interface** (CLI) while still having the benefits of a Graphical User Interface (GUI), with a Naruto-flavoured twist! If you can type fast, Naruto can track your tasks faster than traditional GUI apps.
1. Ensure you have Java `11` or above installed in your Computer.
3. Copy the file to the folder you want to use as the _home folder_ for Naruto.
4. Open a command terminal, `cd` into the folder you put the jar file in, and use the `java -jar naruto.jar` command to run the application.
A GUI similar to the below should appear in a few seconds. Note how the app contains some sample data.
5. Type the command in the command box and press Enter to execute it. e.g. typing **`help`** and pressing Enter will open the help window.
Some example commands you can try:
* `todo borrow book` or `td borrow book` : Adds a todo with the description `borrow book` to your list of tasks.
* `delete 3` : Deletes the 3rd task shown in the current list.
6. Refer to the [Features](#features) below for details of each command.
* Words in `UPPER_CASE` are the parameters to be supplied by the user.
e.g. in `deadline DESCRIPTION /by DD/MM/YYYY HHMM`, `NAME` is a parameter which can be used as `deadline naruto marathon /by 02/02/2020 0200`.
* Parameters must be in fixed order.

* If you are using a PDF version of this document, be careful when copying and pasting commands that span multiple lines as space characters surrounding line-breaks may be omitted when copied over to the application.
Shows a message explaining how to access the help page.
Adds a todo to the task list.
Adds a deadline to the task list.
Format: `deadline DESCRIPTION /by DD/MM/YYYY HHMMâ€‹` or `dl DESCRIPTION /by DD/MM/YYYY HHMMâ€‹`
Adds an event to the task list.
Format: `event DESCRIPTION /from DD/MM/YYYY HHMM /to DD/MM/YYYY HHMMâ€‹`
Shows a list of all tasks in the task list.
Finds tasks whose descriptions contain any of the given keywords.
* The search is case-sensitive. e.g. `return` will not match `Return`
* The order of the keywords does not matter. e.g. `return book` will match `book return`
* Partial words will be matched e.g. `ret` will match `return`
Deletes the specified task from the task list.
* Deletes the task at the specified `INDEX`.
* The index refers to the index number shown in the displayed task list.
* The index **must be a positive integer** 1, 2, 3, â€¦â€‹
* `delete 2` deletes the 2nd task in the task list.
### Marking a task as done : `mark` or `m`
Marks the task at the specified index as done.
* Marks the task at the specified `INDEX`.
* The index refers to the index number shown in the displayed task list.
* The index **must be a positive integer** 1, 2, 3, â€¦â€‹
* `mark 2` marks the 2nd task in the task list.
Unmark a previously marked task at the specified index.
* Unmark the task at the specified `INDEX`.
* The index refers to the index number shown in the displayed task list.
* The index **must be a positive integer** 1, 2, 3, â€¦â€‹
* `unmark 2` unmark the 2nd task in the task list.
Sorts all tasks in the task list in order of occurrence.
Naruto's data is saved in the hard disk automatically after any command that changes the data. There is no need to save manually.
Naruto's data is saved automatically as a `.txt` file `[JAR file location]/src/logs/tasks.txt`. Advanced users are welcome to update data directly by editing that data file.

If your changes to the data file makes its format invalid, Naruto will discard all data and start with an empty data file at the next run. Hence, it is recommended to take a backup of the file before editing it.

Furthermore, certain edits can cause Naruto to behave in unexpected ways (e.g., if a value entered is outside the acceptable range). Therefore, edit the data file only if you are confident that you can update it correctly.

| **Todo** | `todo DESCRIPTION` or `td DESCRIPTION`
e.g., `todo return book` |

| **Deadline** | `deadline DESCRIPTION /by DD/MM/YYYY HHMM` or `dl DESCRIPTION /by DD/MM/YYYY HHMM`
e.g., `deadline return book /by 2/12/2019 1800` |

| **Event** | `event DESCRIPTION /from DD/MM/YYYY HHMM /to DD/MM/YYYY HHMM` or `e DESCRIPTION /from DD/MM/YYYY HHMM /to DD/MM/YYYY HHMM`
e.g., `event CS2103 Tutorial /from 2/02/2024 0800 /to 2/02/2024 0900` |
The structure of this user guide took heavy reference from the user guide of AB3, which can be found [here](https://se-education.org/addressbook-level3/UserGuide.html#features).

implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'

Naruto is a **desktop app for managing todos, events, and deadlines, optimized for use via a Command Line Interface** (CLI) while still having the benefits of a Graphical User Interface (GUI), with a Naruto-flavoured twist! If you can type fast, Naruto can track your tasks faster than traditional GUI apps.
1. Ensure you have Java `11` or above installed in your Computer.
3. Copy the file to the folder you want to use as the _home folder_ for Naruto.
4. Open a command terminal, `cd` into the folder you put the jar file in, and use the `java -jar naruto.jar` command to run the application.
A GUI similar to the below should appear in a few seconds. Note how the app contains some sample data.
5. Type the command in the command box and press Enter to execute it. e.g. typing **`help`** and pressing Enter will open the help window.
Some example commands you can try:
* `todo borrow book` or `td borrow book` : Adds a todo with the description `borrow book` to your list of tasks.
* `delete 3` : Deletes the 3rd task shown in the current list.
6. Refer to the [Features](#features) below for details of each command.
* Words in `UPPER_CASE` are the parameters to be supplied by the user.
e.g. in `deadline DESCRIPTION /by DD/MM/YYYY HHMM`, `NAME` is a parameter which can be used as `deadline naruto marathon /by 02/02/2020 0200`.
* Parameters must be in fixed order.

* If you are using a PDF version of this document, be careful when copying and pasting commands that span multiple lines as space characters surrounding line-breaks may be omitted when copied over to the application.
Shows a message explaining how to access the help page.
Adds a todo to the task list.
Adds a deadline to the task list.
Format: `deadline DESCRIPTION /by DD/MM/YYYY HHMMâ€‹` or `dl DESCRIPTION /by DD/MM/YYYY HHMMâ€‹`
Adds an event to the task list.
Format: `event DESCRIPTION /from DD/MM/YYYY HHMM /to DD/MM/YYYY HHMMâ€‹`
Shows a list of all tasks in the task list.
Finds tasks whose descriptions contain any of the given keywords.
* The search is case-sensitive. e.g. `return` will not match `Return`
* The order of the keywords does not matter. e.g. `return book` will match `book return`
* Partial words will be matched e.g. `ret` will match `return`
Deletes the specified task from the task list.
* Deletes the task at the specified `INDEX`.
* The index refers to the index number shown in the displayed task list.
* The index **must be a positive integer** 1, 2, 3, â€¦â€‹
* `delete 2` deletes the 2nd task in the task list.
### Marking a task as done : `mark` or `m`
Marks the task at the specified index as done.
* Marks the task at the specified `INDEX`.
* The index refers to the index number shown in the displayed task list.
* The index **must be a positive integer** 1, 2, 3, â€¦â€‹
* `mark 2` marks the 2nd task in the task list.
Unmark a previously marked task at the specified index.
* Unmark the task at the specified `INDEX`.
* The index refers to the index number shown in the displayed task list.
* The index **must be a positive integer** 1, 2, 3, â€¦â€‹
* `unmark 2` unmark the 2nd task in the task list.
Sorts all tasks in the task list in order of occurrence.
Naruto's data is saved in the hard disk automatically after any command that changes the data. There is no need to save manually.
Naruto's data is saved automatically as a `.txt` file `[JAR file location]/src/logs/tasks.txt`. Advanced users are welcome to update data directly by editing that data file.

If your changes to the data file makes its format invalid, Naruto will discard all data and start with an empty data file at the next run. Hence, it is recommended to take a backup of the file before editing it.

Furthermore, certain edits can cause Naruto to behave in unexpected ways (e.g., if a value entered is outside the acceptable range). Therefore, edit the data file only if you are confident that you can update it correctly.

| **Todo** | `todo DESCRIPTION` or `td DESCRIPTION`
e.g., `todo return book` |

| **Deadline** | `deadline DESCRIPTION /by DD/MM/YYYY HHMM` or `dl DESCRIPTION /by DD/MM/YYYY HHMM`
e.g., `deadline return book /by 2/12/2019 1800` |

| **Event** | `event DESCRIPTION /from DD/MM/YYYY HHMM /to DD/MM/YYYY HHMM` or `e DESCRIPTION /from DD/MM/YYYY HHMM /to DD/MM/YYYY HHMM`
e.g., `event CS2103 Tutorial /from 2/02/2024 0800 /to 2/02/2024 0900` |
The structure of this user guide took heavy reference from the user guide of AB3, which can be found [here](https://se-education.org/addressbook-level3/UserGuide.html#features).

* A launcher class to workaround classpath issues.

private final Naruto naruto = new Naruto();

+ "training to become a ninja!\nBelieve it!", narutoImage));

* the dialog container. Clears the user input after processing.
PauseTransition pause = new PauseTransition(Duration.seconds(1)); // Adjust the delay as needed
* The Action interface represents an action that can be executed.
* Implementing classes should provide an implementation for the execute method.
* @return A string representing the result of the execution.
* @throws IOException if an I/O error occurs during the execution of the action.
* Represents an action to add a task to a task list.
* Constructs an Add action with the specified task and task list.
* @param task     The task to be added.
* @param taskList The task list to add the task to.
* Executes the Add action by adding the task to the task list and printing the updated task count.
* @return A string representing the result of the execution.
* @throws IOException If an I/O error occurs.
assert this.task != null : "Task cannot be null"; // Add assertion for task
assert this.taskList != null : "TaskList cannot be null"; // Add assertion for taskList
sb.append("Got it! Task added:\n  ").append(task).append("\nNow you have ").append(size)
* Represents an action to delete a task from the task list.
* Constructs a Delete action with the specified task list and index.
* @param taskList the task list to delete the task from
* @param idx the index of the task to be deleted
* Executes the Delete action by adding the task to the task list and printing the updated task count.
* @return A string representing the result of the execution.
* @throws IOException If an I/O error occurs.
assert taskList != null : "Task list cannot be null";
* Represents an action to find tasks based on a given search string.
* Constructs a Find object with the specified search string.
* @param s The search strings used to find tasks.
* Executes the find action by searching for tasks that match the search strings
* @return A string representing the result of the execution.
assert list != null : "Task list cannot be null"; // Assertion to check if the task list is not null
assert !list.isEmpty() : "Task list cannot be empty"; // Assertion to check if the task list is not empty
* Represents an action that prints a goodbye message and exits the program.
* Executes the action by printing a goodbye message and exiting the program.
* @return A string representing the result of the execution.
* Represents an action to greet the user.
* Executes the greet action by printing a greeting message.
* @return A string representing the result of the execution.
return "Hello! I'm Naruto, and I'm training to become a ninja!"
+ "\nBelieve it!\n Enter `help` if you need a guide on the commands to use.";
* This class represents an action to handle an error by printing the error message.
* Constructs a new HandleError object with the specified error.
* @param err the error to be handled
* Executes the action by printing the error message.
* @return A string representing the result of the execution.
assert err != null : "Error object cannot be null"; // Assertion
* Represents an action to display the user guide.
* Executes the Help action by printing a guide.
* @return A string representing the result of the execution.
+ "\ne [DESCRIPTION] /from DD/MM/YYYY HHMM /to DD/MM/YYYY HHMM: add an event"
+ "\nsort: sort all tasks by chronological order"
* Represents an action to list all tasks in a task list.
* Constructs a List action with the specified task list.
* @param taskList the task list to be listed
* Executes the List action by printing all tasks in the task list.
* @return A string representing the result of the execution.
assert taskList != null : "Task list cannot be null";
String result = "Here are the tasks in your list:\n" + taskList.toString();
assert result != null : "Result cannot be null";
* Represents an action to mark a task as completed.
* Constructs a Mark object with the specified task list and index.
* @param taskList the task list to mark the task in
* @param idx        the index of the task to mark
* Executes the action by marking the task as completed and printing a message.
* @throws IOException if there is an error in printing the message
assert taskList != null : "Task list cannot be null";
assert idx >= 0 && idx < taskList.size() : "Invalid task index";
output.append("Great job! You marked that task off your list! Believe it!\n")
* Represents an action to sort the tasks in a task list.
* Constructs a Sort object with the specified task list.
* @param taskList the task list to be sorted
* Executes the sorting action on the task list.
* @return a string representation of the sorted task list
return "Tasks sorted!\nHere are the tasks in your list:\n" + taskList.toString();
* Represents an action to unmark a task in the task list.
* Constructs an Unmark object with the specified task list and task index.
* @param i        the index of the task to unmark
* Executes the unmark action by constructing and returning a message and unmarking the task in the task list.
* @throws IOException if there is an error executing the action
assert taskList != null : "Task list cannot be null";
assert i >= 0 && i < taskList.size() : "Invalid task index";
message.append("You know, sometimes things don't go as planned, but that's okay! ")
.append("\nWe'll get there, one task at a time!\n")
* Exception thrown when an duplicate task is encountered.
* Constructs a new DuplicateTaskException with the specified error message.
* Returns the type of error associated with this exception.
* Exception thrown when an empty command is encountered.
* Constructs a new EmptyCommandException with the specified error message.
* Returns the type of error associated with this exception.
* Exception thrown when a deadline task is created without a specified deadline.
* Constructs a new EmptyDeadlineException with the specified error message.
* Returns the type of error associated with this exception.
* Exception thrown when an event is empty.
* Constructs a new EmptyEventException with the specified detail message.
* Returns the error type of this exception.
* Exception thrown when the current list is empty.
* Constructs a new EmptyListException with the specified detail message.
* Returns the error type associated with this exception.
* Exception thrown when a file is found to be corrupted.
* Constructs a new FileCorruptedException with the specified detail message.
* Returns the error type associated with this exception.
* Exception thrown when an invalid action is performed.
* Constructs a new InvalidActionException with the specified detail message.
* Returns the error type associated with this exception.
* Exception thrown when an invalid command is encountered.
* Constructs an InvalidCommandException with the specified error message.
* Returns the error type associated with this exception.
* Exception thrown when a deadline is invalid.
* Constructs an InvalidDeadlineException with the specified detail message.
* Returns the error type associated with this exception.
* Exception thrown when an invalid event is encountered.
* Constructs a new InvalidEventException with the specified detail message.
* Returns the error type associated with this exception.
* Exception thrown when an invalid index is encountered.
* Constructs a new InvalidIndexException with the specified detail message.
* Returns the error type associated with this exception.
* NarutoException is an abstract class that extends the Exception class.
* It represents a custom exception in the Naruto application.
public abstract class NarutoException extends Exception {
* Enum representing the different types of errors that can occur in the Naruto application.
* Constructs a NarutoException with the specified error message.
* Returns the type of error associated with this exception.
* Creates a NarutoException for an empty command.
* @return the NarutoException for an empty command
return new EmptyCommandException("Looks like you forgot to enter anything after your "
+ "command! \nEnter an input after the command next time.");
* Creates a NarutoException for an empty deadline.
* @return the NarutoException for an empty deadline
return new EmptyDeadlineException("Looks like your deadline is missing a description! "
+ "\nEnter an input after the 'deadline' command to add a deadline.");
* Creates a NarutoException for an empty event.
* @return the NarutoException for an empty event
return new EmptyEventException("Looks like your event is missing a description! \nEnter "
+ "an input after the 'event' command to add an event.");
* Creates a NarutoException for an invalid deadline.
* @return the NarutoException for an invalid deadline
return new InvalidDeadlineException("Looks like you forgot to enter a deadline! \nEnter a"
+ " deadline after the command '/by' to indicate when your deadline is.");
* Creates a NarutoException for an invalid event.
* @return the NarutoException for an invalid event
return new InvalidEventException("Looks like your event doesn't have a valid start or "
+ "end time! \nMake sure your input uses the '/from' and '/to' commands to indicate"
+ "\nthe start and end times of your event.");
* Creates a NarutoException for an invalid command.
* @return the NarutoException for an invalid command
return new InvalidCommandException("Sorry, I didn't catch that... Try entering a valid "
* Creates a NarutoException for an invalid index.
* @return the NarutoException for an invalid index
return new InvalidIndexException("Sorry, I couldn't find the task you indicated... "
+ "Make sure you enter a valid task number!");
* Creates a NarutoException for a corrupted file.
* @return the NarutoException for a corrupted file
return new FileCorruptedException("Oh no! Something seems to have happened to the "
* Creates a NarutoException for an invalid action.
* @return the NarutoException for an invalid action
return new InvalidActionException("I couldn't seem to understand that... Try again!");
* Creates a new instance of NarutoException with a duplicate task error message.
* @return a NarutoException with a duplicate task error message
return new DuplicateTaskException("You already added that task... Try adding "
* Creates a new instance of NarutoException with an empty list error message.
* @return a NarutoException with an empty list error message
return new EmptyListException("You don't have any tasks!");
* The Naruto class represents the main class of the Naruto application.
* It manages the list of actions to be performed and handles exceptions.
private static LinkedList<Action> actions = new LinkedList<>();
* Parses user input and adds the corresponding action to the list of actions.
* Executes the first action in the list of actions.
* If an IOException occurs, it handles the exception by adding a HandleError action to the list.
* @return the result of the executed action
assert action != null : "Action cannot be null";

* @return true if the objects are equal, false otherwise

Task(boolean isMarked, String description, LocalDateTime startDate) {

* The CsvUtil class represents a utility class for working with CSV data.
* It provides methods for constructing CsvUtil objects from CSV strings,

* The 'by', 'from', and 'to' fields are set to null.

* The DateTimeUtil class provides utility methods for formatting and parsing date and time.
private static final DateTimeFormatter INPUT = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("d/MM/yyyy HHmm");

static int parseIdx(String input, TaskList taskList) throws NarutoException {

* Parses the input string into a description.

static String parseDescription(String input) throws NarutoException {
assert input != null : "Input string cannot be null";
* Parses the input string into a deadline description and date/time.
* @param input     The input string to be parsed.
* @return          An array containing the parsed description and deadline.
* @throws NarutoException  If the input string is empty, does not contain "/by", or has an invalid deadline.
static String[] parseDeadline(String input) throws NarutoException {
assert input != null : "Input string cannot be null";
* Parses the input string into an event description, start date/time, and end date/time.
